questions.question_text: Which class do you use to handle an incoming JSON Message as a stream?

discussion.content: The correct answer is C. JsonParser.
A and C ambiguity. JsonParser and JsonReader reads from a stream.
For streaming, jsonParser should be used (C)

Answer - B, C 
... D prints in console and A not works
I've tested A. aproach and does not work in https://www.onlinejspcompiler.com/compileJSP

questions.question_text: Which two approaches would result in the current date being added to the output of a JSP? (Choose two.)
You need to exchange large binary messages using chunks in a WebSocket application. Identify two ways in which you can receive partial messages. (Choose two.)

choices.D: Define an @OnMessage method with byte [] as the first parameter and a boolean as the second parameter.
choices.A: Define an @OnMessage method with a single MimePart parameter.

discussion.content:
Correct answers are C and D
Oracle reference: https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/websocket/MessageHandler.Partial.html
https://abhishek-gupta.gitbook.io/java-websocket-api-handbook/receiving-messages

questions.question_text:
You are working with JMS publish-subscribe operations.
What happens when a producer publishes a message to a topic for which a durable subscription exists but there are no subscribers available?

choices.D: The message publisher is immediately notified about the lack of subscribers and can decide for itself if, and when, to resend.
choices.B: The publisher sends the message. However, it is never consumed because there wasn't anything listening when it arrived, regardless of the message timeout length.
choices.C: The publisher successfully sends a message, which will be consumed later, once there is a subscriber, assuming the message hasn't timed out.
choices.A: The publisher waits for a subscriber, who then consumes it. However, the publisher will time out if no consumer arrives within the given timeout period.
